image.altText: Albanese smiles in the cold dawn light, the warm colour of a grand autumnal tree fills the background behind him.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese believes Australians will welcome the news of a larger than expected budget surplus even as their own budgets continue to take a battering.

title.children: Prime minister spruiks large budget surplus as Australian households battle cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: A woman resting her chin on her hand smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Millions of Australians are opting for career changes, but experts say the window may be closing to get the most out of the "Great Reshuffle". This is how mid-career professionals jumped at the chance for an occupation transformation and set themselves up for a more fulfilling work future.

title.children: Would you take a $50,000 pay cut? Why these mid-career professionals aren't looking back

image.altText: Vladimir Putin's face is lit by warm sunlight. He wears dark sunglasses and a black jacket on black shirt

items.synopsis: As the war grinds on and the traitor Yevgeny Prigozhin is allowed to live on in exile, the question must be asked: Is Vladimir Putin losing his grip on power?

title.children: Russia's elites have a plan in case Putin is toppled. Here's how it could happen

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

items.synopsis: For years, debate has raged in the nation's capital about the need for a federal anti-corruption watchdog — one with actual teeth. Now the National Anti-Corruption Commission is here, so what will it achieve?

title.children: The army major general turned federal anti-corruption boss officially starts today — what's ahead of him?

image.altText: Mitchell Starc pumps both fists as he kneels in the field after taking a catch. Another fielder runs towards him.

items.synopsis: What appears to be a clean catch to remove Ben Duckett is sensationally overturned late on day four of the second Ashes Test, leaving England 257 runs away from victory heading into day five at Lord's.

title.children: Australia denied crucial wicket as third umpire controversially overturns boundary catch to end day four

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ummm, OK. So, the long and short of it is that England needs 257 runs to win this Test match, with six wickets remaining. But that aint the half of it. Glenn McGrath has been blowing up in the TMS commentary box, even going as far as saying that "If that's England taking that catch, that is out". Michael Vaughan, perhaps tongue in cheek, is saying that "rules are rules". "I'll be honest with you, I thought he caught it," Vaughan says. "But I saw the message from Marais Erasmus and he was in control of the ball but not of his body. "Rules are rules. Sorry, Glenn!" As for "not in control of his body", I have no idea what that means. And I hope that someone will explain it who is less sleep deprived in the coming hours so I can try and get my head around it later on today. Because that, for Australian fans, is when the fifth and final day of this intriguing Test gets underway. In theory, it's all still to play for. Australia are still by far the favourites - they're two wickets away from a great big tail - but England will desperately want to believe that they can somehow salvage something after doing their best to throw the Test away.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Stumps: England 4-114 (Duckett 50, Stokes 29)

children.content: Ummm, OK.
(Getty Images)
So, the long and short of it is that England needs 257 runs to win this Test match, with six wickets remaining.
But that aint the half of it.
Glenn McGrath has been blowing up in the TMS commentary box, even going as far as saying that "If that's England taking that catch, that is out".
Michael Vaughan, perhaps tongue in cheek, is saying that "rules are rules".
"I'll be honest with you, I thought he caught it," Vaughan says.
"But I saw the message from Marais Erasmus and he was in control of the ball but not of his body.
"Rules are rules. Sorry, Glenn!"
As for "not in control of his body", I have no idea what that means.
And I hope that someone will explain it who is less sleep deprived in the coming hours so I can try and get my head around it later on today.
Because that, for Australian fans, is when the fifth and final day of this intriguing Test gets underway.

In theory, it's all still to play for. Australia are still by far the favourites - they're two wickets away from a great big tail - but England will desperately want to believe that they can somehow salvage something after doing their best to throw the Test away.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ben Duckett is out and I have no idea how he's got that ball to deep fine leg! He's tried to help it over the slips and somehow Mitch Starc has got it running around from fine leg. Insane. Hang on... what? That's been given not out! The Australians can't believe it! I'm not sure I can either! Starc has caught the ball and then slid with it on the ground. He has clearly caught the ball before putting it on the ground. And it's given as not out? I am going to need to check the rules repeatedly because if that's not out, then none of the "controversial" catches that we've seen can be out either? Extraordinary. "That is the biggest load of rubbish that I've ever seen," Glenn McGrath says on ABC Sport. "If that's not out, every catch I've ever seen taken should not be out. "That is a disgrace. I've seen everything. That is ridiculous." Duckett has a reprieve on 50.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Ridiculous' controversial catch overruled as Ben Duckett earns reprieve

children.content: Ben Duckett is out and I have no idea how he's got that ball to deep fine leg!
He's tried to help it over the slips and somehow Mitch Starc has got it running around from fine leg.
Insane.
Hang on... what?
That's been given not out! The Australians can't believe it!
I'm not sure I can either!
(Getty Images)
Starc has caught the ball and then slid with it on the ground. He has clearly caught the ball before putting it on the ground.
And it's given as not out?
I am going to need to check the rules repeatedly because if that's not out, then none of the "controversial" catches that we've seen can be out either?
Extraordinary.
(Getty Images)
"That is the biggest load of rubbish that I've ever seen," Glenn McGrath says on ABC Sport.
"If that's not out, every catch I've ever seen taken should not be out.
"That is a disgrace. I've seen everything. That is ridiculous."
Duckett has a reprieve on 50.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The short ball brings another batter unstuck, with Root fending at it and sending a simple catch to David Warner at first slip. That was brilliantly bowled by Cummins, first at the body, then just leaving him enough to draw Root into the shot.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cummins gets Root with a rip snorter!!

children.content: The short ball brings another batter unstuck, with Root fending at it and sending a simple catch to David Warner at first slip.
That was brilliantly bowled by Cummins, first at the body, then just leaving him enough to draw Root into the shot.

image.altText: Rachel Perkins with an award.

items.synopsis: Black excellence and community leadership are honoured at the 2023 National NAIDOC Week Awards in Brisbane.

title.children: ‘Stand with us, Australia’: NAIDOC Award winner’s message on the Voice

image.altText: Girl looking straight at camera with spinifex bush in background.

items.synopsis: Kira Gusterson heard rumours of a "Pilbara tax" before she moved to the iron ore mining region — but she was still shocked by the cost of living.

title.children: Living in a mining town when you're not on a mining wage

image.altText: A row of solar panels and wind turbines

items.synopsis: As Queensland continues to take a bold leap forward on renewable energy over the next decade, it's no small irony that revenue from coal is doing much of the heavy lifting to pay for the transition, writes Matt Eaton.

title.children: As Queensland strives to lower emissions, what does it mean for all that coal?

image.altText: Water falling over rock edge

items.synopsis: More than 50 million litres of water is permitted to be extracted from bores within a stone's throw from a UNESCO world heritage rainforest in the Gold Coast hinterland, as groups call for tighter regulation.

title.children: Water destined for plastic bottles is being pumped from beside this world heritage rainforest. Calls are growing for it to end

image.altText: Sign informing of new Spanish mackerel changes is attached to a sign at a jetty.

items.synopsis: Fisheries Queensland says new catch limits are to rebuild the fishery for future generations, but the state's peak seafood body says new reductions to Spanish mackerel quotas are "nonsense".

title.children: Going fishing? There are new rules for Queenslanders from today

image.altText: A group of helmeted police officers walk with riot shields during a protest, lit by bright yellow street light.

items.synopsis: Family and friends of Nahel M, whose shooting by police sparked violent unrest across France, gather for the teenager's funeral in the Paris suburb where he died.

title.children: Hundreds attend teenager's funeral as French police arrest 1300 protestors

image.altText: Passengers queing at airport

items.synopsis: Passengers at Sydney Airport have been hit with a second day of flight cancellations and delays due to gusty winds.

title.children: More than 30 flights cancelled at Sydney Airport on first day of school holidays

image.altText: Port Adelaide AFL players pile on top of each other in the rain at the MCG after winning a game after the siren.

items.synopsis: On a day of shifting momentum in the top eight race, the top two remain the same as the Power down the Dons in a thriller to make it 12 straight wins, and the Magpies destroy the Suns' finals chances at Carrara.

title.children: Bombers hearts broken by Port Adelaide after Magpies masterclass, Crows and Bulldogs win

image.altText: A man looks sad after losing a rugby league match

items.synopsis: Wests Tigers have hit a new low with the joint venture suffering the heaviest defeat in NRL history on a horror night in North Queensland.

title.children: NRL wrap: Records tumble as Wests Tigers concede biggest score in NRL history

image.altText: bus crash

items.synopsis: At least 25 people die after a bus crashes and bursts into flames in India's western state of Maharashtra.

title.children: India bus fire kills at least 25, injures eight

image.altText: Bright red lines coming out the top of a mountian.

items.synopsis: The sacred understanding of El Popo varies from town to town, but many agree that the volcano does not threaten their lives.

title.children: How a Mexican spiritual leader preserves the sacred knowledge of the volcano known as El Popo

image.altText: Afghanistan evacuation

items.synopsis: A report says decisions by US President Joe Biden and his predecessor Donald Trump to withdraw troops from Afghanistan had "serious consequences for the viability" of the former US-backed government.

title.children: Review into evacuation of US troops from Afghanistan critical of Biden, Trump

image.altText: zach in his wheechair smiling, lifting a blue plastic top hat

items.synopsis: The council initially said "site challenges" had made it impossible to make a truly inclusive playground, but have now committed $100,000 to upgrades.

title.children: 'My voice mattered': Seven-year-old wins bid to make Queensland playground more accessible

image.altText: Two women stand in front of an apple display at a supermarket and put them in a small plastic bag.

items.synopsis: The government is expanding a campaign against single-use plastics that it started in 2019, when it banned the thicker plastic shopping bags that customers used to carry home their grocery items.

title.children: New Zealand says it's the first to ban thin plastic bags from supermarkets

image.altText: A medium sized bird, patterned black, white and yellow, on a tree branch.

items.synopsis: There are fewer than 300 regent honeyeaters in the wild but after a concerning breeding season, conservationists are encouraged by recent sightings along the east coast.

title.children: Sightings of one of Australia's rarest birds spark hope, as fight to save species continues

image.altText: Sham wears a purple jumper while holding a jar at a dining table in a house

items.synopsis: It made perfect sense for Sham to start her own business while using her life experience to create accessible beauty products, as figures show people with disabilities are far more likely to be self employed.

title.children: Sham finds it easier to be her own boss while living with disabilities — and she is not alone

image.altText: A woman dressed in purple holding flowers supported by friends and family in purple

items.synopsis: After two decades of silence, Craig Rumsby confesses to the murder of Gulgong teenager Michelle Bright in 1999 and is found guilty.

title.children: 'I've waited 24 years for this': Michelle Bright's mother in tears as Dubbo court convicts killer

image.altText: The entrance to the District Court of Western Australia, with a tree to the right of frame.

items.synopsis: A man is jailed for "unthinkable" offences against his wife and young daughter, that included him taking them hostage and repeatedly raping both of them over a four-day period. WARNING: This story contains distressing content.

title.children: Perth man jailed for 30 years for 'depraved and cruel' sexual offences against wife, daughter

image.altText: a cloud band forms over the kimberley

items.synopsis: Unseasonable rain continues to fall across Australia's north in what's meant to be the region's dry season, helping lower temperatures to near-record levels.

title.children: Why holiday-makers heading north for winter sun could be in for unpleasant surprise

image.altText: A headshot of a young woman with blonde hair looking off camera.

items.synopsis: Police searching for missing Belgian tourist Celine Cremer say a hiker in the area has responded to a plea to come forward to help with any further information about her movements.

title.children: Police searching for missing Belgian tourist speak to hiker about her movements at waterfall track

image.altText: Aboriginal man with Aboriginal flag on a blue T-shirt on a balcony with the beach behind him.

items.synopsis: The collection of staged photographs from the 1900s depicting Birpai people in traditional dress and poses from a bygone era receives heritage listing.

title.children: A family secret led John to preserve heritage photos. But he needs help finding a mystery man

image.altText: A nexus of welded metal coated in sand.

items.synopsis: Coral fields destroyed by weather and bleaching have been growing back at "very successful" rates, thanks to some simple seabed technology and local expertise.

title.children: After a decade of bleaching and cyclone damage, coral shoots of recovery are emerging

image.altText: Jim Chalmers sitting in the House of Representatives. He holds his hand over his mouth.

items.synopsis: The cost-of-living crisis cannot be resolved by one institution alone and raising interest rates isn't the only way to take money out of the economy, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Interest rates needn't be as high as they are, but the government would need to act, top economist says

image.altText: Allan Border smiles while wearing a tuxedo at an awards ceremony

items.synopsis: Australian cricket great Allan Border tells News Corp it will be "a miracle" if he makes it to 80 after living with Parkinson's for years.

title.children: Allan Border reveals he has Parkinson's disease

image.altText: Boxer Tim Tszyu smiles at the camera, with fists clenched and a world title belt slun over his shoulder.

items.synopsis: The slated fight between Tim Tszyu and Jermell Charlo is officially called off as the American decides to battle Canelo Alvarez instead.

title.children: Tszyu and Charlo fight officially called off, with Australian set to be named full world champion

image.altText: An illustration of a woman reading in bed, with a knitted sweater reading "heart ABC Arts".

items.synopsis: Need a good book to snuggle up with as temperatures drop? The stars of this June’s best books include a teacher on a road trip with a corpse, a novelist grappling with her mother’s funeral, and prisoners doomed to fight to the death.

title.children: ‘Quietly devastating’, ‘beautifully told’, a ‘blistering critique’: Five must-read books

image.altText: A man standing with an antique Ford tractor.

items.synopsis: Ron Dehne's interest in the Ford began when he was a teenager working his first job at a regional Victorian dealership. This weekend he plans to open his collection to the public.

title.children: Ron's first Ford tractor got bogged so he bought his second to pull it out. Now there are 120 in the shed
